items.title: Olympic star Courtney Sarault leads Canadian short track women to 3,000m relay bronze
items.summary_auto: Courtney Sarault earned her team-leading fourth medal at the Milano-Cortina Olympics, helping Canada to bronze in the women's 3,000-metre relay on Wednesday.

items.title: 8 skiers found dead, 1 still missing in deadliest avalanche in Northern California in decades
items.summary_auto: Eight backcountry skiers have been found dead and one remains missing after an avalanche near Lake Tahoe in California, officials said, making it the deadliest avalanche in the U.S. in more than four decades.

items.title: Arbitrator settles flight attendant wages at Air Canada, as labour dispute comes to official end
items.summary_auto: An arbitrator reviewing wages for flight attendants at Air Canada has finalized rates at the airline, bringing an end to the labour dispute that saw travel disrupted for thousands of people last summer.

items.title: Canada's Mark McMorris finishes 8th in his fourth Olympics for men's snowboard slopestyle
items.summary_auto: Many eyes were locked on four-time Olympian Mark McMorris in the men's snowboard slopestyle, where he finished short of the podium in eight place overall.

items.title: IDF says it dug up Canadian soldiers' graves to destroy Gaza tunnel
items.summary_auto: The Israel Defence Forces have given CBC News an official explanation for the destruction of a cemetery holding the remains of 22 Canadian soldiers who died serving as peacekeepers in the Middle East in the 1950s and '60s. The IDF says they were destroying a Hamas tunnel. An officer said the IDF had dug to a depth of 20 to 30 metres and could not give any assurance that human remains had been protected or preserved.

items.title: A Pokémon card sold for record-breaking $16M US. An auctioneer from N.L. helped make the deal
items.summary_auto: A deal that saw a Pokémon card sell for a record-breaking $16.5 million US has the finger prints of Whitbourne, N.L. on it.

items.title: A Pokémon card sold for record-breaking $16M US. An auctioneer from Whitbourne helped make the deal
items.summary_auto: A deal that saw a Pokémon card sell for a record-breaking $16.5 million US has the finger prints of Whitbourne, N.L. on it.

items.title: Liberal government expands Express Entry immigration program for some skilled workers
items.summary_auto: Canada is expanding its Express Entry immigration stream so it can bring in a range of skilled workers it says are necessary to grow the economy and defend the country.

items.title: What did we learn from Reality Check: Inside America's Next Top Model?
items.summary_auto: Did the Netflix docuseries Reality Check: Inside America's Next Top Model deliver on its promise to hold those in charge accountable for the most controversial moments on the show?

items.title: U.S. environment agency sued over scrapping scientific rule behind climate protections
items.summary_auto:
A coalition of health and environmental groups sued the Environmental Protection Agency on Wednesday, challenging the rescinding of a scientific finding that has been the central basis for U.S. action to regulate greenhouse gas emissions
and fight climate change.

items.title: Canada should do more to screen visitors from China: former CSIS analyst
items.summary_auto: A new report outlines how several countries are engaging in transnational repression in Canada. As Canada increases economic ties with some countries, like China and India, experts say it should guard against attempts to intimidate members of those diaspora communities in Canada..

items.title: Mitch Marner sends Canada into Olympic semifinals with dramatic overtime winner
items.summary_auto: Mitch Marner scored a dramatic winner at 1:22 of 3-on-3 overtime as the country battled back from a late 3-2 deficit, and survived the loss of captain Sidney Crosby, to pick up a 4-3 victory over Czechia in the quarterfinals Wednesday.

items.title: French activist's killing leads to political furor, 11 arrests and a bomb threat
items.summary_auto: French police investigating the beating of a far-right militant who died of brain injuries have arrested 11 people, prosecutors said on Wednesday, in a case adding fuel to long-standing divides in the country's domestic politics ahead of presidential elections in 2027.

items.title: Storm hits Sask. hard with widespread heavy snow and strong winds
items.summary_auto: The massive winter storm coming out of Alberta is now in full swing across Saskatchewan, and snowfall totals are expected to reach over a foot deep in some areas.

items.title: 4 students sent to hospital in school bus crash near Woodstock, Ont.
items.summary_auto: A school bus packed with approximately 40 students slid off a county road Wednesday morning south of Woodstock, Ont., sending four kids to the hospital.

items.title: IN PHOTOS | Canadian Armed Forces begin Arctic military exercise
items.summary_auto: Operation Nanook, which began in 2007, has evolved into a series of military exercises and drills designed to respond to security threats in Canada's northern frontier.

items.title: Woman alleges Stronach pushed her over arm of chair and tried to rape her, court hears
items.summary_auto: A woman alleged in a Toronto courtroom on Wednesday that Canadian businessman Frank Stronach pushed her over the arm of a chair in his apartment, lifted up her skirt and tried to rape her.

items.title: Female flight attendants say WestJet policies failed to protect them. A court will rule on a settlement
items.summary_auto: A B.C. court will decide in the coming days whether to approve a $4.5-million settlement with female WestJet employees who say they suffered due to the airline’s lack of procedures to combat harassment. WestJet would admit no liability under the terms of the agreement.

items.title: U.S. FDA changes course and agrees to review Moderna's mRNA flu vaccine application
items.summary_auto: Moderna says the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) has agreed to review its influenza ‌vaccine, reversing an earlier decision to reject the application, following modifications from the company.

items.title: Meta no longer designs apps to maximize screentime, Zuckerberg says during social media trial
items.summary_auto: Meta CEO and billionaire Facebook founder Mark Zuckerberg is set to be questioned for the ‌first time in a U.S. court on Wednesday about Instagram's effect on the mental health of young users, as a landmark trial over youth social media addiction continues.

items.title: China fireworks shop explosion kills 12 people amid Lunar New Year celebrations
items.summary_auto: An explosion at a fireworks shop in China's Hubei province on Wednesday killed 12 people, state media reported, the second such explosion as the country celebrates the Lunar New Year.

items.title: No sign of a breakthrough in Russia-Ukraine talks as latest round ends in Geneva
items.summary_auto: The latest U.S.-brokered talks between Russian and Ukrainian envoys over Russia's all-out invasion of Ukraine ended Wednesday with no sign of a breakthrough and with both sides saying the talks were "difficult" as the war's fourth anniversary approaches next week.

items.title: Heart, work and desperation: What an underdog Canadian team needs to do to win Olympic gold
items.summary_auto: It hasn't been a perfect Olympic tournament for Canada. At times, this team has looked disjointed and nervous — especially in a 5-0 drubbing at the hands of the Americans in the preliminary round. But none of that will be remembered if they win Thursday's winner-takes-all gold-medal matchup against the Americans, the latest chapter in one of the best rivalries in all of sport.

items.title: Frustrated families demand changes to Manitoba’s adult abuse registry
items.summary_auto: Families are demanding change to Manitoba’s adult abuse registry, saying it doesn’t protect vulnerable victims and leaves families in the dark on the process of adding alleged abusers.

items.title: Saskatchewan-raised co-owner of non-alcoholic winery lands $1M deal on Dragons' Den
items.summary_auto: ONES is the passion project of Tyler Harlton from Pense, Sask., and Chris Pagliocchini, a scientist for Agriculture Canada. Harlton is no stranger to the agriculture industry himself, having grown up surrounded by Prairie farms.

items.title: A sex offender who received full gender surgery says she'd be safer in a women’s prison
items.summary_auto: A transgender woman incarcerated as a dangerous offender for sex offences wants a judge to order the Correctional Service of Canada to transfer her from the men’s prison system to a women’s institution following her recent gender surgery.

items.title: Child poverty declining in N.S., but thousands at risk without government help: report
items.summary_auto: Without major and sustained intervention by the Nova Scotia government the number of children living in poverty will remain in the tens of thousands, according to a new report.

items.title: National real estate association blames Ontario snowstorm for cooling housing sales in January
items.summary_auto: The Canadian Real Estate Association (CREA) is blaming Old Man Winter as a factor in cool housing sales during the month of January.

items.title: Shark caught on camera for 1st time in Antarctica's near-freezing deep
items.summary_auto: Filmed in January 2025, the camera operated by the Minderoo-UWA Deep-Sea Research Centre was positioned off the South Shetland Islands near the Antarctic Peninsula.

items.title: A chat with Shohei? This tech firm is pitching an AI version of baseball's biggest stars
items.summary_auto: How would you like to have a one-on-one friendship with your favourite professional baseball player? A California-based tech company is pitching exactly that — by building AI-powered avatars of every Major League Baseball star.

items.title: Explosive global measles outbreaks pose risk to Canadian travellers, health officials warn
items.summary_auto: The global spread of measles shows no signs of slowing down in 2026, including explosive outbreaks in travel hot spots like the southern U.S. and Mexico, prompting warnings from public health officials for Canadians to check their vaccination status before heading abroad this winter.

items.title: She wanted a safer social-media platform for her kids — so she made her own
items.summary_auto: Canadian parent Natalie Boll created Tribela as an alternative social platform that prioritizes user safety and well-being, but it's launching just as social media finds itself in the hot seat around the globe. While there's a vocal contingent calling for an Australian-style social media ban for youth, others want a more nuanced approach.

items.title: Kamloops residential school search for potential unmarked graves rules out some areas: First Nation
items.summary_auto: Tk̓emlúps te Secwépemc says findings from three different survey methods overlap in several areas — and those areas will now be the primary focus of the investigation into potential unmarked graves at the site of the former residential school.

items.title: Once again, B.C. NDP frames budget as a ‘balance,’ but this time with more red ink
items.summary_auto: Some B.C. budgets have big spending announcements, tax cuts, or bold new directions that inspire excited press releases from different partisans or stakeholders. The 2026 budget wasn't one of them.

items.title: Rescuers push through winter storm to 6 survivors of California avalanche, with 9 others still missing
items.summary_auto: Rescue crews pushed through the mountainous California wilderness near Lake Tahoe during a snowstorm on Tuesday to rescue six backcountry skiers who survived an avalanche but were trapped by its snow and ice. Nine others from their tour group remained missing.
